p: A number of nearest phylogenomic neighbours to Serratia endophytes ME43 and ME47, including S. marcescens AR_0130, BIDMC 81 and UMH6 (Anderson et al. 2017), originate from the nosocomial environment, whilst S. marcescens sicaria Ss1 was isolated from the haemolymph of worker bees suffering from sepsis and implicated as a new pathogen of honey bees (Burritt et al. 2016). However, isolates of S. marcescens are known to fix nitrogen and act as plant growth promoting endophytic colonisers of rice roots and stems (Gyaneshwar et al. 2001). Nonclinical isolates of S. marcescens have also been used as biocontrol agents (Hallmann et al. 1997) and induce systemic resistance to fungal and viral pathogens (Press et al. 1997), as well as the production of the biologically active compound prodigiosin (Khanam and Chandra 2018).
